intro: Draba amplexicaulis, commonly known as the clasping whitlow grass, is a small, flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The plant typically grows in alpine and subalpine habitats, where it thrives in rocky and well-drained soils. It produces small, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in early spring, and its basal leaves are clasping, wrapping around the stem. Draba amplexicaulis is often found in meadows and scree slopes, and it is adapted to cold, harsh environments.
